sentence:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion,

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried about the excessive screen time during the Pandemic for two reasons. First, we have no idea what the long-term effects of excessive screen time are. The obvious bad effect is that the screen time deprives us of the actual social contact with our family members, friends and coworkers. We can't feel the closeness with our loved ones, nor can we hug them to show our affection.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried about the excessive screen time during the Pandemic for two reasons. First, we have no idea what the long-term effects of excessive screen time are. The obvious bad effect is that the screen time deprives us of the actual social contact with our family members, friends and coworkers. We can't feel the closeness with our loved ones, nor can we hug them to show our affection. We can't share a meal with them, or play with our kids. The second reason is that screen time distracts us from the real world. We are so busy with our screens that we don't notice what is going on around us. We don't notice the people who are sick and need help. We don't notice the people who are in need of a hug. We don't notice the people who are lonely and need a friend.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should be worried about the excessive screen time during the Pandemic for two reasons. First, we have no idea what the long-term effects of excessive screen time are. The obvious bad effect is that the screen time deprives us of the actual social contact with our family members, friends and coworkers. We can't feel the closeness with our loved ones, nor can we hug them to show our affection. We can't share a meal with them, or play with our kids. The second reason is that screen time distracts us from the real world. We are so busy with our screens that we don't notice what is going on around us. We don't notice the people who are sick and need help. We don't notice the people who are in need of a hug, or who are lonely and need a friend. We also lack the time to get enough physical exercise. Screen time is in no way a substitute for actual contact with other human beings. Thus, we should be worried about the excessive screen time and avoid it to a certain extent.
